items.message: High river levels today and overnight may lead to flooding. Flooding is possible on 29 and 30 January 2026. This information is correct as of 3:00pm on Thursday 29 January 2026. The causeway at Sutton Gault has approximately 21cm of water on the road. The causeway at Welney has approximately 3cm of water on the road. There are currently no issues on Earith causeway. Due to the uneven surface of the roads, water may be deeper in places. The Environment Agency are liaising with Norfolk Highways who will decide whether to close the road. For more information about the causeway at Welney, please visit the 'Welney Flood Watch' Facebook group. Please note that the content of this group does not represent the views of the Environment Agency. We are not expecting the situation to escalate, or to issue any further warning messages at this time. We are monitoring rainfall and river levels. The Powdermill Stream in Crowhurst has fallen near to normal following Tuesday's rain. In Bulverhythe river levels remain higher than normal, and minor flooding will continue to affect Bexhill Road Recreation Ground. Small amounts of rain are forecast Thursday evening, Friday evening, and Saturday. River levels will likely rise again Thursday evening, but probably only a very small amount. Minor flood impacts, with water approaching gardens in both Crowhurst and Bulverhythe could be possible on Saturday. River levels in Crowhurst should return near to normal on Sunday. In Bulverhythe river levels could remain higher than normal all weekend. More rain is forecast Monday afternoon, which will cause the river to rise again and further flooding could be possible next week. Consider activating any flood protection products you may have in Crowhurst. This message will be updated by 14:00 30/01/2026.

items.description: River Yeo and River Parrett Moors around Muchelney and Thorney
items.message: The river level at Huish Episcopi is currently 8.90m. The drain level at Huish Episcopi is 8.62m and stable. Flooding will affect the Langport to Muchelney road if this drain level exceeds 7.3m, the Muchelney to Long Load road above 7.86m, the Muchelney to Thorney road above 7.93m and the Muchelney to Draycott road above 8.8m. Property flooding is possible above 8.35m. Pumping will start at Huish Episcopi and Westover stations once river levels allow. The Parrett Relief Channel will be opened once river spillways stop running. Throughout the day isolated showers are forecast, with a band of more sustained rain this evening through to the early hours of Friday morning. We are monitoring the situation closely. Staff are checking the condition of flood banks and spillways. Avoid walking, cycling or driving through flood water. This message will be updated by 1PM on 30/01/2026, or as the situation changes.

The Cuckmere and Bull Rivers are higher than normal, but have fallen significantly from their recent peak. Small amounts of rain are forecast Thursday evening, Friday evening, and Saturday. River levels will likely rise again Thursday evening, but probably only a small amount. Minor flood impacts, with water approaching roads and properties could be possible on Saturday. River levels should finally begin to fall Sunday. However, more rain is forecast Monday afternoon, which will cause the river to rise again and further flooding could be possible next week. Don't put yourself or others at risk. Avoid roads that flood (Mill Lane and Church Road Hellingly, and North Street Alfriston). This message will be updated by 14:00 30/01/2026.

The Western Rother is high at Fittleworth, and higher than normal at Lodsbridge near Selham, but now falling in all communities. Flood impacts will continue to affect Fittleworth Mill and nearby properties, also gardens of isolated mill properties at Lodsbridge near Selham, as well as roads and fields. Between Liss and Midhurst river levels have already returned near to normal. Small amounts of rain are forecast Thursday evening, Friday evening, and Saturday. River levels will likely rise again from 22:00 29/01/2026 in Liss, then again Friday evening, but in most communities should not rise as high as recent events. Only minor flood impacts are expected to affect fields, roads, and gardens, although might get close to recent peaks in Fittleworth. River levels should finally begin to fall Saturday evening in Liss, but not until Sunday in Fittleworth. However more rain is forecast Monday afternoon, which will cause the river to rise again. Keep in place any flood protection products you may have. Including in Lodsbridge and Fittleworth. This message will be updated by 14:00 30/01/2026.

The River Adur has fallen significantly following Tuesday's rain. Only minor flood impacts will continue to affect fields and gardens. Small amounts of rain are forecast Thursday evening, Friday evening, and Saturday. River levels will likely rise again Thursday evening, but probably only a very small amount. Minor flood impacts, with water approaching roads and properties could be possible on Saturday. River levels should finally begin to fall Sunday. However, more rain is forecast Monday afternoon, which will cause the river to rise again and further flooding could be possible next week. Don't put yourself or others at risk. Avoid roads that flood, including the A281 at Mock Bridge. This message will be updated by 14:00 30/01/2026.

The River Ouse is higher than normal, but has fallen significantly from its recent peak. Small amounts of rain are forecast Thursday evening, Friday evening, and Saturday. River levels will likely rise again Thursday evening, but probably only a very small amount. Minor flood impacts, with water approaching roads and properties could be possible on Saturday. River levels should finally begin to fall Sunday. However, more rain is forecast Monday afternoon, which will cause the river to rise again and further flooding could be possible next week. We are operating structures at Pimms Lock and Barcombe to reduce flood risk. Don't put yourself or others at risk. Avoid roads that flood, including Barcombe Mills Road. This message will be updated by 14:00 30/01/2026.

High tides over the next two days may lead to flooding. 
Flooding is possible on 29 and 30 January 2026. Flooding is possible 2 hours either side of high tide times. 
Areas most at risk include Christchurch Harbour and tidal stretches of the Lower Stour and Avon. The detailed tidal forecast for those who use it, is for high water level of 1.38 mAODN at 9:45pm this evening with south easterly force 6 winds. Second high water is forecast at 1.42 mAODN at 7:30am tomorrow, with south westerly force 3 winds. The third high water is forecast at 1.55 mAODN at 8:30pm with southerly force 6 wind. (mAODN is height above average sea level). The river level at the Throop station has also triggered this Alert, and the risk is higher during the next 3 high tides. 
We are closing flood gates and closely monitoring the situation. 
Avoid coastal roads, footpaths and carparks, which may be flooded and refer to local authority websites for road closures. 
This message will be updated by 5:00PM on 30 January 2026 or as the situation changes.

The River Tone level at Currymoor Pumping Station is 7.75m. Water will enter Currymoor via Hookbridge spillway if this level exceeds 7.45m. The Drain level at Currymoor Pumping Station is currently 7.77m. Cutts Road and New Road are both closed. Water is flowing out of Currymoor over Athelney Spillway and the A361 is also closed. The Flood Warning has now been removed. However, a Flood Alert remains in force for the wider area, so flooding of roads and low lying land is still possible. 
Further rainfall is forecast but no further flooding is expected.   
We will continue to monitor the situation and will issue further alerts or warnings if necessary.  
Continue to take care on waterside roads and footpaths and don't put yourself in unnecessary danger. Stay away from floodwater - it contains hidden dangers such as open manhole covers, sewage and chemicals.

The River Tone level at Currymoor pumping station is currently 7.73m. Water will enter Currymoor via Hookbridge spillway whilst this level exceeds 7.45m. The drain level is 7.75m, so Cutts Road and New Road remain closed. Athelney spillway is running and the A361 remains closed. Please refer to www.somerset.gov.uk/roads-travel-and-parking/emergency-road-closure-gates/. We are pumping at Northmoor and Saltmoor stations with additional pumps now running at Northmoor. The River Tone level is still too high for pumping at Currymoor, but we will commence pumping there once river levels allow. 
A band of sustained rain, heavy at times, is forecast overnight. The catchments are saturated, so rivers are forecast to rise again, though not as much as on Tuesday. Any response from the rivers to tonight’s rainfall will occur tomorrow, Friday, as the peak passes down through the system.
We are monitoring the situation closely and checking floodbanks and spillways. Please do not walk, cycle or drive through flood water. This message will be updated by 1 PM on 30/01/2026, or as the situation change

There is no longer a threat of flooding, though standing water and debris may still remain. 
Weather conditions are expected to improve and no further flooding is expected.   
We will continue to monitor the situation and will issue further alerts or warnings if necessary.   
Continue to take care on waterside roads and footpaths and don't put yourself in unnecessary danger. Never drive through flood water,  just 30cm of fast flowing water is enough to move your car.

items.description: Lower Stour at Beaulieu Garden Park Home Site
items.message: High river levels are causing flooding today Flooding is expected on  29th January 2026 .  Flooding is forecast to affect locations near the Lower Dorset Stour, with low lying land and roads expected to be most affected, particularly around Beaulieu Garden Park Home Site. River levels continue to rise on the Lower Dorset Stour. Flooding is affecting Redhill and Wheatplot, Iford Bridge Home Park, Stour Park Homes, Beaulieu Garden Park Home Site and surrounding properties in these areas, today and into tomorrow. We are liaising with emergency services and local authorities and will continue to monitor the situation.  Move family, pets and cars to safety and turn off gas, electricity and water if it is safe to do so and activate any flood protection products you may have.  This message will be updated by 11:00AM on 30 January 2026 or as the situation changes.

The River Lox has now fallen significantly following Tuesday's rain. Small amounts of rain are forecast Thursday evening, Friday evening, and Saturday. River levels will likely rise again Thursday evening. From 03:00 30/01/2026 minor flood impacts could affect fields, roads, and gardens near the top of the River Lox, including isolated riverside properties at Loxley Bridge on Wrotham Hill, Dunsfold and Petworth Road, Chiddingfold. From 08:00 30/01/2026 minor flood impacts could also affect fields, roads and gardens near Brewhurst Mill on Brewhurst Lane and the Onslow Arms, Loxwood. Only minor flood impacts are expected. River levels should finally begin to fall Sunday. However, more rain is forecast Monday afternoon, which will cause the river to rise again and further flooding could be possible next week. Consider activating any flood protection products you may have. Continue to operate private water control structures at Brewhurst. This message will be updated by 14:00 30/01/2026.

The Langney Haven is high following Tuesday's rain. Minor flood impacts will continue to affect fields and parkland including Shinewater Park. Small amounts of rain are forecast Thursday evening, Friday evening, and Saturday. River levels will likely rise again Thursday evening, but probably only a very small amount. Minor flood impacts, with water approaching gardens of Langney Green, could be possible on Saturday. River levels should finally begin to fall Sunday, but not far. More rain is forecast Monday afternoon, which will cause the river to rise again and further flooding could be possible next week. We are operating structures at Fence Bridge and Crumbles to reduce flood risk. Consider activating any flood protection products you may have in Langney Green. This message will be updated by 14:00 30/01/2026.

High river levels on Thursday may lead to flooding.

Flooding is affecting low lying land, roads and footpaths close to the river.  Flooding of Golf Links Road and Moreton Common Road will continue today 29/01/2026. Ditches around Fort Holiday Park will struggle to drain while river levels are high. From 08:30 29/01/2026, gardens at Nicholas Close, Brading may flood while the river is tide locked. Further rain is forecast on Friday 30/01/2026. River levels will continue to reduce in Alverstone and Sandown throughout today. At Brading, it is possible further garden flooding may occur during each high tide for the next couple of days. 
We are checking rivers for blockages and operating Bembridge sluices 
Consider activating any flood protection products you may have . Including in Alverstone. 
This message will be updated by 12:00PM on 30 January 2026 or as the situation changes.

Minor flood impacts affecting fields, roads, and gardens will continue to affect the A29, properties on Lower Street and Swan Corner, Pulborough and Bridge Cottages, Greatham. Over high tides (07:30 and 20:15 on 29/01/2026, and 08:45 on 30/01/2026) water will be high up banks near Houghton Bridge, Amberley, Houghton, and Arundel, but as tides are currently low, property flooding is not expected in these communities. Small amounts of rain are forecast Thursday evening, Friday evening, and Saturday. However, we predict that river levels at Pulborough will keep falling. River levels will not fall far, and with more rain forecast Monday afternoon, as well as higher tides, further river rise and flood risk could be possible next week. We are closely monitoring the situation and our pumps in Pulborough are running to help reduce flood risk. Consider activating any flood protection products you may have in Pulborough, Amberley and Arundel. This message will be updated by 18:00 30/01/2026.

Residents are advised to prepare property resilience measures and ensure that pumps are working where they have been installed. Residents may experience inundation of septic tanks and sewer systems. Properties may experience flooding in cellars in affected areas. Flooding of roads is expected, please take care when driving.  We are closely monitoring the situation .  If you have a pump, make sure it is working and switched on. Think about alternative power sources in case of power cuts Please do not drive through floodwater as this may cause bow waves. The River Tone level at Currymoor pumping station is currently 7.73m. Water will enter Currymoor via Hookbridge spillway whilst this level exceeds 7.45m. The drain level is 7.75m, so Cutts Road and New Road remain closed. Athelney spillway is running and the A361 remains closed. Please refer to www.somerset.gov.uk/roads-travel-and-parking/emergency-road-closure-gates/. We are pumping at Northmoor and Saltmoor stations with additional pumps now running at Northmoor. The River Tone level is still too high for pumping at Currymoor, but we will commence pumping there once river levels allow.
A band of sustained rain, heavy at times, is forecast overnight. The catchments are saturated, so rivers are forecast to rise again, though not as much as on Tuesday. Any response from the rivers to tonight’s rainfall will occur tomorrow, Friday, as the peak passes down through the system.
We are monitoring the situation closely and checking floodbanks and spillways. Please do not walk, cycle or drive through flood water. This message will be updated by 1 PM on 30/01/2026, or as the situation changes

items.description: Groundwater flooding for the North Winterborne, south of the A354
items.message:
High groundwater levels are expected to cause flooding. 
Flooding is expected from 26 January 2026 
Groundwater levels in West Dorset remain high. Areas that could be affected include: Winterbourne Whitechurch, Winterbourne Kingston, Winterbourne Zelston and Newton Perverill. The groundwater level at the Delcombe Wood borehole has risen to 137.37m, and is expected to rise due to rainfall. Residents are advised to prepare property resilience measures and ensure that pumps are working where they have been installed. Residents may experience inundation of septic tanks. Flooding of roads is expected, take particular care when driving, both for your own safety and to prevent flooding. 
We are closely monitoring the situation . 
If you have a pump, make sure it is working and switched on. Think about alternative power sources in case of power cuts . 
This message will be updated by 2:30PM on 03 February 2026 or as the situation changes.

items.description: River Yeo and River Parrett Moors, low lying properties around Muchelney
items.message:
The River Yeo level remains high; the drain level at Huish Episcopi Pumping Station is 8.60m and stable. Property flooding is possible above 8.35m. Flooding affects the Langport to Muchelney road when this drain level exceeds 7.30m, the Muchelney to Long Load road above 7.86m, the Muchelney to Thorney road above 7.93m and the Muchelney to Drayton road above 8.8m. For flood levels refer to https://check-for-flooding.service.gov.uk/. Pumping will start at Huish Episcopi and Westover stations once river levels allow. The Parrett Relief Channel will be opened once spillways stop running.
A band of sustained rain, heavy at times, is forecast overnight. The catchments are saturated, so rivers are forecast to rise again, though not as much as on Tuesday. Any response from the rivers to tonight’s rainfall will occur tomorrow, Friday, as the peak passes down through the system.
We are monitoring the situation closely. Staff are checking the condition of flood banks and spillways. Avoid driving through flood water. This message will be updated by 1 PM on 30/01/2026, or as the situation changes

items.description: Salt Moor and North Moor including Moorland
items.message:
Water levels remain high and expected to continue to cause flooding. Locations most affected will be low lying land and roads around Moorland including Horlake, Saltmoor, Fordgate and Chadmead. The level in Currymoor has stopped rising and is currently stable, though still very high and may rise further as a result of tonight’s rain. Athelney spillway is still running into Saltmoor and Northmoor. However we are pumping at Northmoor and Saltmoor stations and additional high volume mobile pumps are now running at both locations also, which will help to slow the rate of rise of floodwater. 

A band of sustained rain, heavy at times, is forecast overnight. The catchments are saturated, so rivers are forecast to rise again, though not as much as on Tuesday. Any response from the rivers to tonight’s rainfall will occur tomorrow, Friday, as the peak passes down through the system.
Act on your flood plan if you have one. Remain aware of local water levels and weather conditions. This message will be updated by 1 PM on 30 January 2026 or as the situation changes.

High groundwater levels may lead to flooding. 
Flooding is possible from 30/01/2026, after above average rainfall in January. 
Minor flood impacts could affect fields, the recreation ground, and a small number of cellars in Denton. A small amount of water may appear on Denton Road. Groundwater at Houndean Bottom borehole is expected to stop rising around the 31/01/2026. However, small amounts of rain are forecast Friday and Saturday, with the suggestion of more rain next week. Further groundwater rise could be possible next week, which may cause water to flow towards Vicarage Close and affect areas near the three ponds in South Heighton. If rain continues, flood impacts may remain until mid February. 
We are closely monitoring the situation , including rainfall, groundwater and forecasts. 
Don't put yourself or others at risk . Avoid roads that flood (Denton Road). Ensure pumps work. 
This message will be updated by 6:00PM on 02 February 2026 or as the situation changes.

items.description: Groundwater flooding in upper River Ems Valley
items.message:
High groundwater levels may lead to flooding. 
Flooding is possible from 31/01/2026, after above average rainfall in January. 
Springs will appear, water will be in fields, and small amounts of water could flood down roads. Groundwater at Compton borehole is expected to pause rising around the 01/02/2026. However, small amounts of rain are forecast Friday and Saturday. More rain is suggested next week. If further rain occurs further groundwater rise could cause more water to flow along Stoughton main road, the road from East Marden, between Cooks Lane and Barley Mow in Walderton, the B2146 near Woodlands Lane. Towards the end of the first week of February water could also affect cellars in Stoughton and Walderton. 
We are closely monitoring the situation , including rainfall, groundwater and forecasts. 
Don't put yourself or others at risk . Avoid roads that flood (Stoughton, Walderton). Ensure pumps work. 
This message will be updated by 6:00PM on 02 February 2026 or as the situation changes.

items.description: Groundwater flooding in West Dean, Singleton, Charlton, East Dean and Chilgrove
items.message:
High groundwater levels may lead to flooding. 
Flooding is possible from 31/01/2026, after above average rainfall in January. 
Springs will appear, water will be in fields, and small amounts of water could flood down roads near Chilgrove and East Dean. Groundwater at Chilgrove borehole is expected to pause rising around the 01/02/2026. However, small amounts of rain are forecast Friday and Saturday. More rain is suggested next week. If further rain occurs next week, then by 08/02/2026 more water will flow along roads, and groundwater could begin to affect the ability of the sewage network to operate in East Dean, Charlton, Singleton and West Dean, and may start to appear in a small number of basements.

items.description: Middle Hampshire Avon at Southampton Road Retail and Business Parks, Salisbury
items.message: This is a Flood Warning Update. River levels remain high due to recent rainfall and high groundwater levels. Flooding is expected at locations around the Middle Hampshire Avon, with low lying land and roads expected to be most affected, particularly around Southampton Road Retail Park, Salisbury Business Park on Dairy Meadow Lane and Dairyhouse Bridge Caravan Site. Further rain is expected tonight and tomorrow. We are closely monitoring the situation. Please avoid using low lying footpaths and any bridges near local watercourses, and do not attempt to walk, cycle or drive through flood water. People in this area should continue to monitor local water levels and weather conditions. This message will be updated by 4:00PM on 30 January 2026 or as the situation changes.

items.description: Middle Hampshire Avon at The Friary and City Centre, Salisbury
items.message: High river levels are expected to cause flooding today.  Flooding is expected on 29 January 2026 .  Locations most affected will be Fisherton Street, Bridge Street, Mill Road, Crane Street, New Street, Catherine Street, Brown Street, Exeter Street, Friary Lane, Greyfriars Close and Wiltshire College. Further flooding is expected throughout the evening as river levels remain high due to recent rainfall and high groundwater levels. Further rain is forecast tonight.  We are monitoring rainfall and river levels .  Activate any flood protection products you may have .  This message will be updated by 2:00PM on 30 January 2026 or as the situation changes.

items.description: Lower Stour from Longham to Christchurch

floodArea.county: Bournemouth, Christchurch and Poole, Dorset Council

items.message: This is a Flood Warning Update. Increased flooding is forecast to impact the Lower Dorset Stour due to increased flows and tidal influence. Impacts are most likely in undefended areas of Willow Way, Marina View, Watermead, Priory Quay, Convent Meadows, Sopers Lane and Mayors Mead Car Park. Further rain is expected tonight and tomorrow. We are closing flood gates and will continue to closely monitor the situation. We advise people to move cars away from low lying areas. Take care and avoid walking, cycling or driving through flood water. Refer to local authority websites for road closures. This message will be updated by 5:00PM on 30 January 2026 or as the situation changes.

High river levels on Thursday may lead to flooding. 
Flooding is possible on 29 January 2026 , as a lot of rain has been recorded this week (40mm). 
Flooding could affect low lying land, including gardens at Rectory Lane and Rookery Lane, Broughton.  Today (29/01/2026) will be mostly dry. Further rain is forecast on Friday (30/01/2026). River levels and flood risk are likely to remain elevated for most of this week. 
We are monitoring rainfall and river levels and will ensure the river is kept free of reported blockages. 
Consider activating any flood protection products you may have . 
This message will be updated by 12:00PM on 30 January 2026 or as the situation changes.

items.description: Groundwater flooding in Finchdean, Dean Lane End and Rowlands Castle
items.message:
High groundwater levels may lead to flooding. 
Flooding is possible from Monday 02/02/2026 because of a very wet January 2026. 
In the last 24 hours, the groundwater level at Finchdean has risen by 67cm. It is possible that pumps which prevent water from entering property may be required from Monday 02/02/2026. During heavier rainfall events, surface water could affect property. On Friday 30/01/2026 and Saturday 31/01/2026, up to 15mm of rain is forecast on each day. Sunday 01/02/2026 and Monday 02/02/2026, are expected to be drier. Groundwater levels will rise into next week. If heavy rain affects the valley in the coming days, then it is possible that roads and more properties could be affected later in the week. 
We are closely monitoring the situation and liaising with the Flood Action Group. 
Residents are advised to prepare property resilience measures and ensure that pumps are working where they have been installed . 
This message will be updated by 6:00PM on 05 February 2026 or as the situation changes.
